questions.text: A middle-aged male presents with a painless, slow-growing swelling in the neck. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is performed. For which of the following thyroid cancers is FNAC least likely to provide a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follicular thyroid cancer

Option B:

FNAC cannot be useful for making a diagnosis of follicular thyroid cancer as it cannot distinguish between benign and malignant thyroid tumors.

FNAC cannot reliably distinguish between benign and malignant follicular neoplasms because the diagnosis of follicular thyroid cancer requires evidence of vascular or capsular invasion, which cannot be assessed on aspiration cytology.

Explanation:

Option A. FNAC is highly effective for diagnosing papillary thyroid cancer due to characteristic cytological features such as nuclear grooves and pseudoinclusions.

Option C. FNAC can suggest a diagnosis of medullary thyroid cancer by demonstrating amyloid and calcitonin-rich cells; however, serum calcitonin levels and genetic testing are also important for diagnosis.

Option D. FNAC can often suggest anaplastic thyroid cancer due to the presence of highly atypical cells and necrotic material; however, the aggressive nature of the disease often requires rapid additional diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

Educational Objective:

FNAC has limitations in diagnosing follicular thyroid cancer because it requires histological evidence of capsular or vascular invasion to differentiate between benign and malignant lesions, which cannot be determined by cytology alone.

questions.text: Fine needle aspiration cytology is not able to detect which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular cancer

 

Option C:

 

FNAC cannot differentiate between benign follicular adenomas and follicular carcinoma due to the requirement of histologic evaluation of the capsule for invasion, which is not possible with FNAC.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Papillary carcinoma: FNAC is usually diagnostic for papillary carcinoma due to its distinctive cytological features, including nuclear grooves and psammoma bodies.

 

Option B: Hashimoto thyroiditis: FNAC can suggest this diagnosis when lymphocytes and Hurthle cells are present, indicating an autoimmune process.

 

Option D: Medullary cancer: FNAC can suggest medullary carcinoma by demonstrating amyloid and calcitonin in cells, but a definitive diagnosis often requires additional tests such as serum calcitonin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While FNAC is a useful tool in the initial assessment of thyroid nodules, it cannot distinguish between follicular adenoma and follicular carcinoma due to the necessity of examining capsular and vascular invasion histologically.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1089

questions.text: Psammoma bodies are seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenocarcinoma of colon

 

Option B:

 

Psammoma bodies are not a common feature of colon adenocarcinomas. They are more typically associated with certain other epithelial tumors, like ovarian and thyroid papillary carcinomas.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Papillary carcinoma of thyroid: It is known to frequently have psammoma bodies, which are calcified concentric structures found within the tumor tissue.

 

Option C: Meningioma: This benign brain tumor often contains psammoma bodies, contributing to its classic histological appearance.

 

Option D: Papillary cancer of the ovary (serous cystadenoma of the ovary): Similar to papillary thyroid carcinoma, ovarian papillary tumors can also exhibit psammoma bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psammoma bodies are calcified structures often found in certain neoplasms such as papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, meningioma, papillary cancer of the ovary (serous cystadenoma of the ovary) and occasionally in mesothelioma but are not typically seen in adenocarcinoma of the colon.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1098

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with loss of function mutation in RET proto-oncogene?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hirschsprung disease

 

Option C:

 

Loss-of-function mutations in the RET proto-oncogene are associated with Hirschsprung disease, a congenital disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon, leading to bowel obstruction and megacolon. In contrast, gain-of-function mutations in the RET proto-oncogene are associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes, including medullary carcinoma of the thyroid and pheochromocytoma. Pituitary adenomas are not linked to RET mutations.

 

Explanation:

 

Options A and B: Gain of function mutations in RET proto-oncogene occurs in medullary thyroid carcinoma (Option A) and pheochromocytoma (Option B) as part of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A and 2B syndromes.

 

Option D: Pituitary adenomas are typically associated with mutations in other genes such as MEN1 and are not directly linked to RET proto-oncogene mutations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Loss of function mutation in the RET proto-oncogene is associated with Hirschsprung disease, which is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon, leading to functional intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following papillary thyroid carcinoma variants is not associated with aggressiveness?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Follicular variant

 

Option A:

 

Follicular variant: While the follicular variant of papillary carcinoma tends to have a better prognosis compared to classical papillary carcinoma as it is less aggressive in its behavior.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Unencapsulated: Lack of encapsulation is a feature associated with increased aggressiveness in papillary carcinoma. Encapsulation can help contain the tumor and prevent its spread. So, this option matches the criteria for aggressiveness.

 

Option C: Tall cell variant: The tall cell variant of papillary carcinoma is associated with a more aggressive behavior compared to classical papillary carcinoma. Therefore, this option matches the criteria for aggressiveness.

 

Option D: Oxyphilic (Hurthle) cell type: Hurthle cell carcinoma, a variant of follicular thyroid carcinoma, is generally considered more aggressive than papillary carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The follicular variant of papillary carcinoma tends to have a better prognosis compared to classical papillary carcinoma as it is less aggressive in its behavior.

 

Follicular variant of papillary thyroid carcinoma (FV-PTC)

 

  • The most common variant after classical PTC.
  • Divided into:
    • Encapsulated, non-invasive → behaves very indolently, almost like a benign lesion (these are sometimes reclassified as "NIFTP" – non-invasive follicular thyroid neoplasm with papillary-like nuclear features).
    • Encapsulated, invasive → slightly increased risk, but generally still favorable prognosis.
    • Infiltrative (unencapsulated) → more aggressive, higher risk of nodal metastases.
  • In general, when the term “follicular variant” is used without qualifiers, it usually refers to the encapsulated type, which is not aggressive.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1091

questions.text: Which of the following thyroid carcinomas originates from C-cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medullary carcinoma

 

Option A:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma originates from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid, which produce calcitonin.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Follicular carcinoma: This carcinoma arises from follicular cells, which are responsible for synthesizing and secreting thyroid hormones, not calcitonin.

 

Option C: Papillary carcinoma: The most common type of thyroid cancer, also derived from follicular cells, and not from C-cells.

 

Option D: Anaplastic carcinoma: A rare and highly aggressive thyroid cancer that arises from follicular cells and has a poor prognosis; it does not originate from C-cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is derived from C-cells, which are distinct from follicular cells that give rise to the more common papillary and follicular thyroid carcinomas. Medullary thyroid carcinoma is characterized by the production of calcitonin and may be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2).

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1095

questions.text: Hurthle cell tumor variant of which of the following tumors is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follicular carcinoma

 

Option B:

 

Hurthle cell tumors are a variant of follicular thyroid carcinoma. They are characterized by large cells with granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm and are often encapsulated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Papillary carcinoma: This is the most common type of thyroid carcinoma, but Hurthle cell tumors are not classified as papillary carcinoma.

 

Option C: Medullary carcinoma: This type arises from parafollicular C cells, which is not related to the follicular cells that give rise to Hurthle cell tumors.

 

Option D: Anaplastic Carcinoma: Hurthle cell carcinoma is not a variant of Anaplastic carcinoma. Anaplastic Carcinoma is seen in old age and has the worst prognosis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hurthle cell tumors are a variant of follicular thyroid carcinoma, which are characterized by distinctive large cells with abundant granular cytoplasm and are encapsulated. They differ from papillary and medullary thyroid carcinomas both in terms of their origin and histological appearance.

 

Summary Table:

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1089

choices.text: Psammoma body present in 50% cases
Early metastasis with poor prognosis

questions.text: About papillary carcinoma of thyroid, all are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Early metastasis with poor prognosis

 

Option C:

 

Although papillary thyroid carcinoma can metastasize early, particularly to regional lymph nodes, it usually maintains a good prognosis and is often curable.

 

This does not worsen prognosis significantly.

 

Even with lymph node metastasis, survival remains excellent.

 

Distant metastasis (to lungs or bone) is rare, and when present, prognosis may be slightly worse but still much better than most other cancers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Associated with BRAF mutation: Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is associated with BRAF gene mutation.

 

Option B. Psammoma body present in 50% cases: Psammoma bodies are calcifications that are often found in papillary thyroid carcinoma but may not be present in as many as 50% of cases.

 

Option D. Spreads by the lymphatic route: This is true. Papillary thyroid carcinoma commonly spreads to regional lymph nodes via lymphatics.

 

This typically involves:

 

  • Cervical lymph nodes (neck)
  • Jugular lymph chain

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid typically has a favorable prognosis, even with early lymphatic spread, contrasting with other cancers where early metastasis often correlates with a poor prognosis.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1086

questions.text: Most common thyroid cancer after radiation exposure is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Papillary cancer

 

Option A:

 

  • There is a marked increase in the incidence of papillary carcinomas among children exposed to ionizing radiation (particularly during the first 2 decades of life).
  • Deficiency of dietary iodine (and so, goiter) is linked with a higher frequency of follicular carcinomas.

 

Exposure to ionizing radiation, especially during the first two decades of life, significantly increases the risk of developing papillary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Medullary cancer: Medullary thyroid cancer arises from parafollicular C-cells and is typically associated with genetic mutations in the RET proto-oncogene, not with radiation exposure.

 

Option C: Follicular cancer: While not associated with radiation exposure, the incidence of follicular carcinoma is higher in areas with iodine deficiency.

 

Option D: Anaplastic cancer: Anaplastic thyroid cancer is a rare and aggressive form of thyroid cancer that generally occurs in the elderly population and is not associated with radiation exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common thyroid cancer associated with childhood exposure to ionizing radiation, which can significantly increase the risk of this cancer.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1086

questions.text: Orphan Annie eye nuclei appearance is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Papillary carcinoma thyroid

 

Option A:

 

This thyroid cancer is noted for its unique nuclear features, which include enlarged, overlapping nuclei with finely dispersed chromatin giving an "empty" appearance, also known as 'Orphan Annie eye' nuclei.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

'Orphan Annie eye' nuclei is a distinctive cytological feature of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid, which is important for diagnosis and distinguishing it from other neoplasms.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1087

questions.text: Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid is associated with which of the following syndrome:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MEN II

 

Option B:

 

MEN II syndrome includes medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC), pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenomas or hyperplasia. MEN II is further divided into MEN IIA (Sipple syndrome) and MEN IIB, with both subtypes having a strong association with MTC.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: MEN I – Incorrect. MEN I typically involves tumors of the parathyroid glands, pituitary gland, and pancreas, not medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option C: Li-Fraumeni syndrome – Incorrect. This is a hereditary cancer syndrome associated with a variety of cancers, including sarcomas, breast cancer, and brain tumors, but not specifically medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Option D: Hashimoto’s thyroiditis – Incorrect. This is an autoimmune disease of the thyroid gland and is not directly associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, although thyroid cancer can occur more frequently in the setting of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is commonly associated with Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type II (MEN II), which includes two subtypes, MEN IIA and MEN IIB, both characterized by the occurrence of medullary thyroid carcinoma and pheochromocytomas. MEN IIA also includes parathyroid adenomas or hyperplasia.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1129

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a family history of endocrine neoplasia presents with a thyroid nodule. Histological examination of the nodule after fine-needle aspiration biopsy reveals amyloid deposition. Which of the following types of thyroid carcinoma is the woman most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medullary

 

Option C:

 

Originates from the parafollicular C-cells of the thyroid and is associated with amyloid deposition, which is derived from calcitonin produced by tumor cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Papillary carcinoma: This is the most common type of thyroid cancer and is characterized by branching papillae and often presents with psammoma bodies. It is not typically associated with amyloid deposition.

 

Option B: Follicular carcinoma: It does not characteristically involve amyloid deposition.

 

Option D: Anaplastic carcinoma: This is a highly aggressive and undifferentiated form of thyroid cancer. Amyloid is not a feature of anaplastic thyroid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is unique among thyroid cancers as it originates from parafollicular C-cells and is associated with amyloid deposition within the tumor, which can be identified histologically. This type of carcinoma can occur sporadically or as part of the multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 syndromes.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1091

choices.text: Papillary carcinoma of thyroid

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents with a solitary thyroid nodule. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is performed, and the pathologist reports that the distinction between a benign and a malignant lesion cannot be made with certainty. Which type of thyroid nodule is most notorious for requiring histologic examination beyond FNAC to establish a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Follicular carcinoma of thyroid

 

Option D:

 

FNAC cannot distinguish between follicular adenoma and follicular carcinoma because the diagnosis of carcinoma depends on the identification of capsular and/or vascular invasion, which requires histologic examination of the surgical specimen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Papillary carcinoma of thyroid: Papillary carcinoma typically shows distinctive nuclear features on FNAC which are usually diagnostic, making it sufficient for diagnosis.

 

Option B: Carcinoma breast: FNAC can be diagnostic for breast carcinoma, showing malignant cells, but a core biopsy is often preferred for additional architectural and immunohistochemical information.

 

Option C: Adenocarcinoma lung: While FNAC can suggest adenocarcinoma of the lung by demonstrating malignant glandular cells, a core biopsy is usually required for complete characterization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While FNAC can suggest follicular neoplasm, it cannot differentiate follicular carcinoma from follicular adenoma as the latter requires the identification of capsular or vascular invasion, which necessitates histological examination of the entire surgical specimen.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1089

questions.text: A 56-year-old female presents to her primary care physician with a history of a progressively enlarging neck mass over the past several years. She reports no symptoms of dysphagia, dyspnea, or hoarseness. Physical examination reveals a palpable, non-tender, firm mass in the anterior neck consistent with a long-standing goitre. Which malignancy develops in long standing goitre?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Follicular carcinoma

 

Option B:

 

It's more commonly associated with iodine deficiency and can arise in the setting of a long-standing goiter. It requires a full histological evaluation to distinguish it from benign follicular adenomas.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Papillary carcinoma: This is the most common thyroid malignancy and can occur with or without a preceding goiter. It has a distinctive histological appearance but is not particularly associated with iodine deficiency or long-standing goiters.

 

Option C: Medullary carcinoma: This type of cancer arises from parafollicular C cells producing calcitonin and is commonly associated with genetic syndromes like MEN 2, rather than long-standing goiters.

 

Option D: Anaplastic carcinoma: This is a very aggressive form of thyroid cancer that can arise de novo or from existing well-differentiated tumors but isn't specifically linked to long-standing goiters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid is associated with iodine deficiency and is more likely to develop in the setting of a long-standing goiter. This malignancy is notorious for hematogenous spread and requires thorough histological examination to differentiate it from benign conditions.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1089

questions.text: All of the following are feature of granulomatous thyroiditis except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Painless

 

Option C:

 

Painless Granulomatous thyroiditis, also known as subacute thyroiditis or De Quervain's thyroiditis, is typically a painful condition. It presents with a tender, swollen thyroid gland and is often preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection. Pain in the neck, jaw, or ear is a common feature, and tenderness is elicited on palpation of the gland.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A:  In the initial phase of granulomatous (subacute) thyroiditis, there may be a transient hyperthyroid phase due to the inflammatory destruction of thyroid follicles leading to the release of preformed thyroid hormones into circulation.

 

Option B:  Following the hyperthyroid phase of granulomatous thyroiditis, there is a hypothyroid phase as the damaged thyroid may be temporarily unable to produce sufficient hormones. This is usually self-limited, and normal thyroid function often returns, but some patients may develop permanent hypothyroidism.

 

Option D:  Granulomatous thyroiditis is characterized histologically by granuloma formation with giant cells. These multinucleated giant cells are part of the body's response to inflammation and are involved in the degradation of thyroglobulin, which is released during the follicular destruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granulomatous thyroiditis is the most common cause of thyroid pain, not a painless condition.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1093
